summary: Build a concert-travel deal comparison app that compares total trip cost across tickets, VIP packages, lodging, and multiple transportation modes (plane/train/taxi, etc.), and can flag and auto-save better-value upgrades (better seats, first class, nicer rooms) than the user’s originally saved choices, with teen-friendly safety/social features and cohesive quirky vintage travel-ticket branding.
architectural_notes: Core value: optimize total trip cost (tickets + VIP + lodging) rather than ticket price alone.
Bundle generation requires integrating event ticket sources, VIP package availability, and hotel search/pricing.
Adding social + photo features introduces major privacy/safety/compliance needs (age gating, parental consent, biometrics/face recognition, moderation, and data retention controls).
Brand direction: quirky vintage travel aesthetic (old passport/ticket motif) with an optional fun tagline for teen-friendly appeal.
Scope intent: broaden supplier integrations beyond a single provider (multiple ticket + accommodation/travel sources + VIP packages), increasing aggregation/normalization needs.
Visual theme update request: switch primary palette to army green + navy blue + black.
Support configurable display names/labels for major app sections (e.g., Profile, Memory Finder, Groups) so the UI can be rebranded without changing underlying feature behavior.
Logo asset needs revision: old passport look while also clearly showing a perfectly preserved/readable airplane ticket element and a visible concert ticket element.
Ensure branding/logo components (including login page) use responsive sizing to fill their intended container (e.g., correct width/height/object-fit) rather than rendering too small.
Change initial routing/landing behavior so the unauthenticated login/sign-in page is the default first screen.
known_issues: AI was unable to complete the build request; user asked to retry ('Try doing it again').
Current logo does not clearly show a readable preserved airplane ticket and visible concert ticket within the old passport motif; user requested a fix.
Login page logo is rendered too small; user wants it sized to fit/fill the logo box.
Welcome/sign-in screen copy is not matching desired text; user wants it to read "Welcome to EOA" (currently includes garbled/extra characters like "W").
Login/auth flow currently forces account creation and/or redirects users to Google/Instagram login instead of the intended sign-in experience.
On the default onboarding/sign-up screen, the top "Sign in" button routes users to an email/third-party quick sign-in hub (TikTok/YouTube/Gmail/etc.) instead of the intended sign-in method.
Auth/session handling issue: logging out of the external email/third-party quick sign-in provider logs the user out of TripTally unexpectedly (session not independent/persistent).

existing_features.title: Create the core user flow to compare an event trip’s total cost by combining concert tickets, official VIP packages (when available), and lodging for a user-selected travel window (days before/after the concert).
Implement an event and pricing input model that supports comparing multiple ticket sources, multiple VIP package options, and multiple hotels for the same trip, including currency-aware totals.

Add bundle generation logic that: (a) includes official VIP packages when the user indicates one exists and (b) if no suitable VIP package exists, generates an alternative “VIP-style” bundle by pairing the cheapest viable hotel options with standard ticket offers (without claiming official VIP).
Provide a saved comparisons feature tied to the signed-in Internet Identity user so travelers can save, revisit, and delete trip comparisons (event + inputs + generated bundle results).
Design and implement a coherent visual theme for the app (colors, typography, spacing, layout) that fits a concert-travel savings product and apply it consistently across all screens.

Create the initial set of screens/components: (1) Landing/Home with product explanation, (2) Trip Builder form, (3) Results/Bundle Comparison view, (4) Saved Comparisons view, and basic navigation between them.
Add static generated image assets to support branding and the landing page, and render them from frontend/public/assets/generated (not via the backend).

Add an under-18 safety gate for any action that implies purchasing tickets or packages by requiring the user to confirm either (a) they are 18+ or (b) they have parent/guardian permission before the UI shows any purchase-directed call-to-action (CTA) such as “Continue to buy”, “Book hotel”, or external links (if/when present). The confirmation must be explicit (checkbox + short consent text) and stored per signed-in user so it persists across sessions.

Create a “Memory Finder” feature that lets a signed-in user create photo albums and upload photos tied to their account. Each photo must support manually tagging people in the photo by linking the tag to a known user profile (selected from the user’s friends list or by entering a principal). Provide pages/components to: create/delete albums, upload/delete photos, and view an album with its tagged people.

Implement a safe alternative to automated face scanning by adding a “Tag people” workflow on each uploaded photo that supports (a) manual tagging and (b) optionally drawing/adjusting simple rectangular “face boxes” for each tag (no automatic recognition). The UI should explain that automated face recognition is not performed.

Add a “Groups” (concert travelers) feature as an asynchronous group chat system (no real-time sockets) where signed-in users can join/create a group associated with a trip comparison (or a generic group) and post messages. Provide a simple group list, group detail view with message history, and the ability to leave a group. Use polling via React Query refetch intervals for updates.

Update app navigation to include entry points for the new social/safety features (e.g., “Memory Finder” and “Groups”), keeping the UI teen-friendly and simple. Ensure navigation remains functional across desktop and mobile breakpoints.

Create a new primary brand logo image in a quirky vintage style: an old passport silhouette that visually reads like a concert ticket (inside pages resemble a concert ticket), with worn edges, faded ink, and stamped/used texture; include a preserved, layered airplane ticket element where seat number, cabin class (first/economy), and airline text are still visible.
Add a centralized branding config (app name and optional tagline) and use it consistently across the UI shell: TopNav brand area, HomePage hero, Footer copyright line, and the HTML document title.
Replace the current HomePage hero logo asset reference with the new vintage passport-ticket logo and ensure alt text and sizing remain appropriate for accessibility and responsive layouts.
Create a new authenticated "Profile" page that acts as a personal dashboard and surfaces the signed-in user’s saved trip plans (saved comparisons) so users can quickly revisit them without searching.
Add routing and navigation entry points for the new Profile page, and adjust the post-login experience so users can reach their saved trip plans immediately after signing in.

Ensure the profile creation flow continues to work with the new Profile dashboard by guiding first-time signed-in users through profile setup before the Profile dashboard attempts to show personalized content.

Update the global Tailwind theme tokens to use an army green, navy blue, and black palette by adjusting the CSS variables in `frontend/src/index.css` (e.g., `--background`, `--card`, `--primary`, `--secondary`, `--accent`, `--muted`, `--border`, `--ring`, and related `--sidebar-*` tokens) so the app’s primary actions and highlights read as army green, secondary/navigation accents read as navy, and surfaces/backgrounds stay black/near-black.

Verify readability and accessibility after the palette change by ensuring sufficient contrast for common text styles (`text-foreground`, `text-muted-foreground`) and interactive states (hover/focus ring) against the black/near-black surfaces.
Update the centralized branding configuration to reflect the new app name (and tagline if desired), and ensure any branding text that currently includes the old name is updated accordingly.
Ensure the browser/document title reflects the renamed app consistently (including when navigating between routes).
Replace remaining hard-coded occurrences of the old app name in the UI shell and pages with the centralized branding value, and update any derived identifiers that still reference the old name.

Rename the app’s user-facing page/feature labels across the UI (navigation, page headings, buttons, and helper text) using the previously suggested unique names, without changing routes or functionality. Apply these exact label mappings:
- App name (branding): "TripTally"
- Trip Builder page label: "RouteRally"
- Saved Trips / Saved Comparisons label: "CostCompass"
- Memory Finder label: "EchoPass"
- Groups label: "NovaTrips"
- Profile label: "VibeVoyager"

Generate an updated primary logo image that still reads as an old passport, but clearly contains (1) a perfectly preserved, layered airplane ticket with legible details and (2) a visibly distinct concert ticket element within the composition (worn passport texture + readable ticket elements).

Update the centralized branding configuration to reference the updated logo asset path (and adjust the logo alt text only if needed to remain accurate), so the new logo appears anywhere `branding.logo.primary` is used (e.g., TopNav and Home page hero).

Update the unauthenticated ("Sign In") states of the app pages so the brand logo is displayed at a larger size that fills/fits its visual container box (not rendered as a small icon). Apply this to the sign-in views for Profile (/profile), Saved Comparisons (/saved), Memory Finder (/memory-finder), and Groups (/groups), using the existing branding logo from `frontend/src/config/branding.ts`.

Identify and fix the user-facing text shown during the sign-up / first-time onboarding flow so it no longer displays the garbled copy "W" and "Welcome To The EOA", and instead shows clear English welcome copy consistent with the current branding (e.g., "Welcome to TripTally").

Update the unauthenticated sign-in / welcome screen UI so that it displays the exact heading text "Welcome to EOA" (with this casing) on pages that prompt the user to sign in, and ensure no extra/garbled characters appear in the welcome copy.
Make the login/sign-in screen the first (default) screen users see by changing the `/` (index) route to render a dedicated sign-in page instead of the current Home/Landing page.

Ensure the default sign-in page shown at `/` displays the exact heading text "Welcome to EOA" (English text, exact casing) and includes a working Sign In button that initiates Internet Identity login; after a successful login, redirect the user to `/profile`.
Ensure the app’s sign-in flow uses Internet Identity as the only authentication method and does not redirect users to any Google/Instagram (or other third-party) login/account-creation pages.

Harden the Internet Identity provider configuration so it cannot accidentally resolve to a non-Internet-Identity provider: if the configured provider URL is missing/invalid, fall back to the official Internet Identity provider URL, and surface a clear English error if login cannot start.

Fix the unauthenticated sign-in screen component to render the provided title prop (and keep all user-facing copy in English), rather than hardcoding a heading that can become inconsistent across pages.
Investigate the previous deployment failure and re-run the build/deploy so the current project deploys successfully.

Require authentication before a user can access app features (treat the experience as a phone-app-style “you must sign up/sign in first” flow): when an unauthenticated user navigates to any non-auth entry route (e.g., /home, /trip-builder, /results, /saved, /memory-finder, /groups, /profile), redirect them to the default sign-in route (/) and do not allow the protected page content to render until authenticated.

Update the default sign-in screen at (/) to read like a standard mobile app onboarding/sign-up page using English copy: clearly present that the user can create an account or sign in via Internet Identity (passkeys), and ensure the primary call-to-action is phrased accordingly (e.g., “Create account / Sign in”).

Fix the unauthenticated sign-in screen component to render the provided props for its heading/title rather than hardcoding the heading text, so different pages can display consistent, intentional onboarding headings while staying in English.

Update top navigation labeling/behavior so it does not misleadingly present the default route (/) as “Home” when it is the sign-in/onboarding screen; ensure the nav item label for (/) is accurate for unauthenticated users (English), and navigation remains functional on desktop and mobile breakpoints.

Update the default sign-in page at `/` to display the exact heading text "Welcome to EOA" (English text, exact casing) and ensure the rest of the onboarding copy is clear English and consistent with an Internet Identity (passkey) sign-in experience (no mention of email/social-provider sign-in).

Ensure the TopNav "Sign In" action for unauthenticated users uses the same Internet Identity login flow as the main sign-in page and does not navigate users to any email/social-provider login hub or third-party authentication screen.

Harden the frontend build/runtime configuration so the Internet Identity provider URL cannot be missing or resolve to a non-Internet-Identity provider: ensure the value used by the login flow is always defined and defaults to the official Internet Identity provider URL when misconfigured.

Prevent auth/session coupling with any external email/social-provider sign-in by ensuring the app’s authenticated session is based only on Internet Identity, so logging out of an external provider (e.g., Google) cannot log the user out of this app.

Add transportation options to the trip-building flow so users can compare total trip cost across multiple transport modes (at minimum: plane, train, and taxi/ground transport) and carry these inputs through to results and saving.

Implement better-value upgrade detection in the local comparison logic so the app can flag higher-quality options that are cheaper than the user’s planned choice (tickets: e.g., “front row”; transport: e.g., “first class”; hotels: e.g., higher star rating / nicer room type), using only the offers the user entered.
When saving a trip comparison, auto-save the flagged upgrade alternatives alongside the user’s originally planned choice, and surface both in the saved-comparisons (CostCompass) view.
Ensure any new or modified user-facing copy introduced for upgrade flagging and transportation comparison is clear English and does not introduce non-English or garbled text.

new_feature_requests.summary: Compare concert ticket prices across sources for selected events
Generate bulk/bundled deals combining tickets + hotel (and optionally VIP) for a trip
Detect and include official VIP packages (e.g., early entry) when available
If no suitable VIP package exists, recommend hotels and assemble an alternative VIP-style bundle focused on lowest total cost
Support trip-length flexibility (days before/after concert) and compare total cost for different date ranges
Teen-friendly UX and onboarding (simple, fun, easy to use for teenagers)
Under-18 parental permission / consent gating before purchasing tickets or packages
Face scanning in uploaded photos to identify/tag people and link to profiles (to add friends and reduce meeting strangers)
Social layer: user profiles/friends and group chats with concert travelers worldwide (including travel/overseas coordination tied to saved packages/hotels)

Extend the backend user profile model and APIs to support: (1) storing parental-permission/age-confirmation status, and (2) a basic friends list that allows a user to add/remove other users by principal (and optionally store a display label). Update frontend queries/mutations to read/write this data using React Query.
Create a quirky vintage logo/brand concept (old passport shaped like a ticket, with preserved airplane ticket details) plus optional fun tagline
Expand comparison coverage beyond Ticketmaster to aggregate tickets across many ticket websites plus accommodations/travel websites and band VIP packages
Add user profiles that surface saved trip plans/bookings so on login users can quickly revisit without searching
Update app color scheme/theme to use an army green, navy blue, and black palette

Ensure the updated palette is applied consistently across key screens and navigation (Home, Trip Builder, Results, Saved Trips, Memory Finder, Groups, Profile) without introducing hard-coded colors that conflict with the theme tokens.
Change/rename the app name (update centralized branding config and UI references)
Rename in-app feature/page labels (e.g., Profile, Memory Finder, Groups, Saved Comparisons) to new unique names and reflect them consistently across navigation and relevant UI text
Adjust login page logo sizing so the logo fills/fits its container box (not rendered too small)
Update the sign-in / welcome page copy to say "Welcome to EOA" (and remove any unwanted extra/garbled characters)
Make the login/sign-in page the first (default) screen users see, and ensure it displays the heading text "Welcome to EOA"
Fix authentication flow so users are not forced to create an account or redirected to Google/Instagram login; use the intended sign-in method consistently
Add a mobile-app-style sign-up/sign-in page that lets users create an account themselves and optionally use email to fast-track sign-in (social-media-style onboarding UX)

When a user saves a trip (tickets/VIP/hotel/transport), automatically flag better-value upgrades (e.g., front-row seats, first-class tickets, nicer hotel rooms) that are cheaper than what they planned to pay
Extend trip cost comparison beyond flights to include other transportation options (e.g., train and taxis/ground transport) and choose the cheapest total option
If the system flags a better ticket/deal, auto-save the flagged alternative alongside the user’s originally saved ticket/deal (not just the box-office saved choice)

Extend the backend trip-comparison data model so a saved TripComparison can (a) store the user’s originally planned/saved choices and (b) store a set of auto-flagged “better-value upgrades” (e.g., better seats/first class/nicer room) that are cheaper than the user’s planned choice.

projectName: Concert travel deal comparison app (tickets + VIP + hotel bundles)
